content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun visual challenge suitable for Reverse mode.

You might want to change the title of the clash to be somewhat related to the task but vague enough to not provide any hints :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash ! Can be done in 2/3 minutes when you have figured out what to do.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Many of the reverse challenges that I have done seem to just be basic arithmetic (a*a-a) or simple string manipulation(hello,ello,llo,lo,o). This challenge feels slightly more interesting while being easy enough to guess.

- Please standardise all empty cells in both the top and bottom grids as spaces. E.g. Test 1; please format

 - -
  -

as (note the trailing spaces)
    
 - -
  - 
    

- Include test cases where the top grid has rows that have leading and/or trailing spaces. An extreme example of this is when the top (or bottom, for that matter) grid is completely blank (comprised of spaces only).

- Include test cases where some of the corresponding cells in the top and bottom grids (cells in the same position) contain the same character. An extreme example of this is when the top and bottom grids are exactly the same.
OK, I made these changes. I also simplified my Python solution slightly to make sure all of the test cases follow the rule you gave about trailing spaces.

The title doesn't appear in a Reverse mode clash (otherwise, all clashes with Reverse and other modes enabled would require vague titles). Therefore, using more descriptive and relevant titles is a good idea to make searching easier.
OK, I gave it a more descriptive title. Thanks for the feedback @User123 and @5DN1L.
Hm, I don't seem to see the changes reflected. Did you save your edits?

I did save my edits, but they didn't go through. Are you aware that it often takes more than a minute to save this tiny amount of data, and the saving doesn't go through sometimes with no explanation? I don't want to have to make those edits again, especially since it's a perfectly valid clash without them.
This is frustrating and I don't want to have to keep making the same changes until saving is fixed. I don't mean to be oppositional.

When you edit the test cases, CodinGame
will recompile and test all your new test cases to make sure your suggested solution works. I believe this is the reason for the delay in saving edits.

I agree that it's very frustrating and that CodinGame has to do something about their UX. But for now, check to see if CodinGame saved your unpublished edits. If not, you will unfortunately have to make the edits again.

Then, when trying to save the changes, wait for the submit button to become clickable and submit again for the second time. An error should pop up stating that you do not have the most recent version, but after refreshing the page, your edits should show up. This is how I usually make edits to test cases on my clashes/puzzles.

Let me know if that works for you.

Running the test cases seems to take less than 5 seconds; I'm not sure what the additional minute or more is for. I could transfer this data more quickly than that on a Commodore 64's 300-bps modem.
Would it be possible to consider the lack of spaces at the end of some lines as part of the challenge? Considering how short and straightforward the sample solution is, I don't think this is likely to prevent people from solving the problem.
I made the other changes again (a new test case to cover leading/trailing spaces and other identical characters). I'm hoping you'll be OK with leaving the older test cases as-is.
